featured.text: For one thing, only the husk of the cactus is used for generating biofuel, while its inner flesh is still preserved for food.
The cactus’s thick outer layer (i.e., husk), with all those spines, had always been viewed as a waste product until researchers developed a biogas generator to turn the husks into electricity.

As she points out they are not sitting at a table where rich people would sit, her parents calculate the value of the desert hills, the blooming cactus, the calls of eagles, and one another’s company.
Moreover, the cactus requires minimum water, and thus is not grown on traditional agricultural pasture.
The prickly pear cactus is such a powerful symbol in Mexico that it occupies a prime spot on Mexico’s national flag.

other.text: The pilot project dedicated to developing the cactus biogas generator began in the south of Mexico City.
The generator is now in place at the cactus market, where the vendors are enthusiastic about this new way to utilize the tons of cactus husks that once went directly into the trash.
Which of the following statements about the prickly pear cactus is true? (A)
What advantage does the prickly pear cactus have over other biofuel crops?
The area produces 200,000 tons a year of prickly pear cactus—up to 10 tons of which ends up as waste on the floor of the cactus market each day.

definition.zh_def: 仙人掌，一種多肉植物，通常生長在乾燥的環境中，具有刺和肉質的莖。
definition.en_def: A cactus is a type of succulent plant that typically grows in dry environments and has spines and fleshy stems.
definition.example: The cactus in my garden blooms beautifully every spring.
